title: Royal Edinburgh; Her Saints, Kings, Prophets and Poets
author: Oliphant, Mrs. (Margaret)
snippet: They proudly said 'that if it was    not stayed both he and the Baillies should repent it.'

title: The Story of My Life, volumes 4-6
author: Hare, Augustus J. C. (Augustus John Cuthbert)
snippet: The large rooms were silent and hushed, though many persons,chiefly Bruces and Baillies, were moving in and out.

title: The Story of My Life, volumes 4-6
author: Hare, Augustus J. C. (Augustus John Cuthbert)

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Here all signs of the band came to an end,for most of the folk of the place knew naught of the airt of the gipsyflight, and such as knew were loth to tell, being little in a mood toincur the Baillies' wrath.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Fromthis man he had learned that the Baillies had with them one whom he didnot know for certain, but shrewdly guessed as the laird of Barns.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: For thehorns of the Ruthven's company (which was far the larger) threatened toenclose the Baillies, and cut off their retreat.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Ye maun ken thatfor lang we've had a bluid-feud wi' that clan, for the Baillies are ayegentrice and hae nae trokins wi' sic blaggard tinklers.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: She was of the clan of the Baillies, the great gipsies of Tweeddale andClydesdale, offshoots of the house of Lamington, and proud as the devilor John Faa himself.

title: Noctes ambrosianæ,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: " Doctor Pringle and the Mistress took up their first abode at Leith, in the Exchange Hotel, one of the quietest houses for persons and families of sedate and clerical habits, in the whole country  for having brought in their own carriage, the distance from Edinburgh  was of no consequence, though Mrs. Pringle daily grudged the high shilling toll on Leith Walk, and thought the Baillies of Edinbro'  great extortioners for exacting so much."

title: Noctes ambrosianæ,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: When the book was sent out a' printed to Yarrowside, od ! I just read the maist feck on't as if I had never seen't nfore ; and as for that sang in particular, I'll gang before the Baillies the morn, and tak' my affidavy that I had no more mind o' when I wrote it, or how I wrote it, or ony thing whatever concerning it no more than if it had been a screed o' heathen Greek.

title: Noctes ambrosianæ,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: The mist's just clearing away from my eyes every moment ! How I'll enlighten the Baillies when I win back to the Manse.

title: Noctes ambrosianæ,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: He -is deuced severe on the Glasgow Baillies and Professors ! I am told.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: We had but one trouble all day: when a strolling piper came and sat in the same wood with us ; a red-nosed, bleareyed,  drunken dog, with a great bottle of whiskey in his pocket, and a long story of wrongs that had been done him by all sorts of persons, from the Lord President of the Court of Session who had denied him justice, down to the Baillies of Inverkeithing who had given him more of it than he desired.

title: [Works]
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis

title: Peter's letters to his kinsfolk.
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: This was a cruel scene ; but the awe with which some of the rural pastors about me seemed to survey now and then the grand knot of Baillies, was sufficient  to convince me that it might have happened very naturally.

title: Peter's letters to his kinsfolk.
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: The gorgeous array of Baillies,  it is to be supposed^ had caught his eye on first entering the Presence-room, and dazzled it so much, that it would have required some time to recover its power of discrimination.

title: The Edinburgh tales.
author: Johnstone, C. I.
snippet: I believe the Lukes are now, by this marriage, something  sib to mysel' either through the Lock- harts, or the Baillies o' the Upper Ward ; and here is a letter in Mrs. Luke's own hand, franked by the Ambassador, hoping, for auld langsyne, we will that's you and me, mem receive the young folks and her at Halcyon Bank on the 23d.

title: The Edinburgh tales.

title: House of Achendaroch. An old maid's story
author: Cameron, Mary Emily.
snippet: Mr. MacTavish the Fiscal, the Provosts pastand present, to say nothing of the Baillies, were all in greatglee thereat.
